newsitem.title: RUSSIA: FOCUS-Russian economy still not growing in May.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Russian economy still not growing in May.

text.p: Russia's economy continued to contract in May, according to official figures released on Tuesday which confirmed the gloomy predictions of ministers who have put off a forecast recovery to next year.

The State Statistics Committee said gross domestic product (GDP), the broadest measure of economic activity, in the first five months of this year was 0.2 percent lower than a year earlier. GDP in May was 0.4 percent lower than in May 1996.

Earlier this year officials hailed an upturn in year-on-year GDP as a sign the economy was recovering after seven years of contraction, but the figures proved to be a false dawn, and recent data suggest the economy is bumping along the bottom.
Ministers have now revised their forecast of up to two percent growth this year to a decline of up to two percent, and say the recovery will not set in in earnest until next year.
But there are already signs of recovery.

Industrial output in the first five months of this year was 0.5 percent higher than a year earlier, and unemployment at the end of May was seven million people or 6.9 percent of the workforce, unchanged from a month earlier.
Inflation has continued to slow, with the year-on-year rate hitting a record low 14.6 percent in May.
But wage arrears, part of a larger web of unpaid bills choking the economy, rose again to 53.92 trillion roubles ($9.36 billion) at the start of June, after edging down in April.

Russia continued to run a trade surplus, which widened to $6.8 billion in the first four months of this year from $5.5 billion a year earlier, but that reflected a large drop in imports as well as a modest pick-up in exports -- further evidence that the economy is still in the doldrums.

Other figures released by the Central Bank showed that Russia's deficit on the overall balance of payments -- the net outcome of all its trade and financial transactions with the rest of the world -- doubled to $22.6 billion in 1996.

That was largely due to Russian savers and investors continuing to shift resources out of the country, with households buying $8.5 billion in cash to hold at home and companies leaving $4.2 billion of export receipts abroad in foreign currency.

The government had to spend $2.8 billion of its currency reserves, borrow $3.8 billion from the International Monetary Fund and $4.7 billion from other international organisations and foreign governments to plug the deficit.
It also rescheduled or failed to pay $11 billion in debt payments, so that actual debt service on the $127 billion foreign debt was only $7.1 billion in 1996 instead of the $18.1 billion due.

The Russian European Centre for Economic Policy, an institute sponsored by the European Union, said Russia would have run a deficit on its current account -- the balance of its trade in goods and services with the rest of the world -- in 1996 of $1.7 billion instead of the $9.3 billion surplus it actually posted, if it had paid all the interest and debt due.
But if countries owing Russia money had also paid up, Russia would have had a current account surplus of nearly $8 billion.
The figures also showed an improvement in the balance of payments towards the end of 1996, as Russian and foreign investors became more reassured about political stability.

Direct investment in the Russian economy rose to $2.5 billion in 1996 from $2.0 billion in 1995, while portfolio investment -- purchases of shares and bonds -- rose to $7.5 billion, mostly in the last three months, from $100 million.
